lexUnit.name: beaker.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a cylindrical glass container used for drinking or in a laboratory

sentence.text: He hands her a beaker of champagne .
An Italian private buyer paid £11,536 for just one beaker with this design .
She took his beaker away and placed it on the balcony wall .
The British figured pottery took the form of colour-coated drinking beakers , the earliest products dating to the second half of the second century .
Approximate measurements of the enthalpy change for reactions in solution can be made using a simple calorimeter such as a polystyrene beaker .
The highest price of £14,059 was bid by a Taiwan dealer for two 12 in-high wine beakers decorated with feathers ( estimate £1,500 to £2,000 ) , the ceramic decanters of the pre-refrigeration age .
The gurgling as Samuel drained every last drop of milkshake from the beaker through a coloured straw had started to grate on the photographer 's already frayed nerves .
The Archimandrite raised his beaker towards the women , and drank fully ; whereupon his servant poured for him again .
Huy allowed a beaker to be filled so as not to transgress the etiquette of hospitality , but he did not propose to drink any wine .
Ingrid Karnstein swept a row of glass beakers to the floor with one gloved hand , the crashing sound muffling the noise of the door .
Drinking blackcurrant juice from a plastic beaker , her hair in a bob that looks as though she did it herself with kitchen scissors , she looks like a child .
Mike filed his copy at quarter past four and went back to his desk and plastic beaker of stewed tea feeling well satisfied .
Ryker passed her once more , glancing at her , cradling a plastic beaker of tea in his hand .
To his surprise , Molly threw away the dregs of tea in her beaker and held it out for him to fill with the frothing liquor .
In front of me in these three glass beakers are samples of urine taken from three patients .
The tube is then placed in a beaker of water .
The male patient is asked to pass a little urine ( perhaps the equivalent of two tablespoons ) into one glass beaker and then to pass more into a second beaker .
For example , a beaker of water may have a temperature of 50°C but it does not have heat .
